article.title: Stochastic lattice model of synaptic membrane protein domains

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure schematically depicts a stochastic lattice model for what process?
choices: Neural signal transmission across a chemical synapse.
Reaction-diffusion dynamics of synaptic receptors and scaffolds.
Memory formation and learning in neurons.
The formation of glycine receptor clusters.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does Figure 2 demonstrate about the relationship between mean-field equations and stochastic simulations for receptor and scaffold diffusion?
choices: Mean-field equations always accurately predict the average molecule occupancies.
Mean-field equations and stochastic simulations show excellent agreement for small 𝜖.
Individual receptor and scaffold concentration profiles always take the form of Gaussian distributions.
Molecular crowding has no impact on the diffusion profiles.

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 3 explores the Mean-Squared Displacement (MSD) of receptors in crowded diffusion-only systems. What conclusion can be drawn about the effect of molecular crowding on the MSD?
choices: Molecular crowding has no significant effect on the MSD of receptors.
Receptors initially located in crowded regions show increased initial MSD slope compared to free diffusion.
All receptors have the same effective diffusion coefficient independent of their initial location.
Molecular crowding can lead to spatially heterogeneous MSD curves at early times.

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 4 investigates the diffusion profiles for receptors and scaffolds with distinct diffusion coefficients (νr > νs). What effect does increasing νr/νs have on the receptor concentration profile?
choices: The receptor profile becomes increasingly symmetric.
The receptor profile always remains monotonic.
The receptor profile becomes increasingly multimodal.
The receptor profile becomes indistinguishable from the scaffold profile.

multiple_choice_question.text: This equation, known as the Master Equation (ME), describes what aspect of the system?
choices: The deterministic behavior of receptor and scaffold concentrations.
The probability distribution of the system being in a specific state at a given time.
The diffusion currents of receptors and scaffolds in the cell membrane.
The average receptor and scaffold occupancies at steady state.

multiple_choice_question.text: This mean-field equation describes the time evolution of scaffold concentration (s) for what specific reaction?
choices: Removal of receptors from the cell membrane via endocytosis.
Insertion of scaffolds into the cell membrane from the cytoplasmic "bulk".
Binding of scaffolds to receptors.
Trimerization of gephyrin scaffolds.
